author: The Telegraph
title: A more robust approach to private company investment
text: Crowdfunding has become a fashionable form of alternative finance in recent years because it can be a fast way to raise capital. But it has flaws - parts are unregulated and it works mainly on platforms, most of which do not conduct research or due diligence. Rockpool is an investment firm which aims to build wealth by focusing on direct investment in private companies. Rockpool’s model is built around transparency, thorough due diligence and flexibility. Rockpool offers direct investment into private companies which qualify for the Enterprise Investment Scheme. Rockpool’s investment team have many years of experience in selecting companies with sound growth prospects. • Rockpool’s Network of investors includes many entrepreneurs, which means it can help you find off-market opportunities for investment and use its expertise to carry out thorough due diligence. • To stay up-to-date on your investments, you can attend regular meet the management days hosted by Rockpool as well as view your portfolio online. • Rockpool helps investors diversify by selecting from a wide range of sectors. It focuses on profitable businesses - but also backs companies with a clear route to profitability and a proven model. Rockpool is a specialist private company investment firm. It has a network of more than 1,000 entrepreneurs and professionals who invest directly in the opportunities it offers. Thorough analysis Rockpool has been investing in private companies for more than 20 years. The combined experience of its Network also helps it to find off-market opportunities and have insight into many different sectors. Rockpool do all the hard work finding the companies undertaking thorough due diligence and negotiating the best terms for investors. Transparency Investors receive information via reports and directly from the management teams of the companies who speak at regular reporting days. You can monitor your portfolio online. Bringing companies and investors together Rockpool presents investment options after conducting thorough due diligence on each company. It acts as a facilitator between investors and the companies. What Rockpool invests in UK-managed, unQuote: d companies. Helping investors diversify by selecting from a wide range of sectors, Rockpool focuses on profitable businesses raising between £2 million and £5 million, but also backs companies with a clear route to profitability. Our three strategies Rockpool has three investment strategies. • “Growth” is for those who want to invest in fast-growth companies. • “Next Generation” is for those looking to protect wealth and shelter this from inheritance tax. • “Exit Focus” is for investors who want a predictable exit as soon as possible after the three-year minimum holding period and investments which are asset-rich. Tax reliefs EIS offers a host of reliefs to improve your potential returns including income, capital gains and inheritance tax reliefs. Portfolio objective Rockpool aims to help investors build a diverse portfolio which fits their chosen risk profile. This portfolio consists of four direct private company investments which qualify for the Enterprise Investment Scheme. The investments benfit from EIS tax reliefs. Rockpool contributes to the success of these companies by giving them access to flexible capital and an insightful contact network. We look for profitable companies with proven models. We aim to create a diverse, balanced portfolio. We negotiate terms on behalf of investors and help each company deliver on the agreed investment objectives. Next generation Mr Simons wants to use a Rockpool EIS portfolio to protect his investments from inheritance tax. He also has some gains made over the past three years (£15,000) that he wants to defer from capital gains tax. He makes a net investment of £100,000. This brings him 30 per cent income tax relief of £44,657 and CGT relief of £4,200, which increases his portfolio immediately to £148,857. The investment grows at 5.2 per cent a year. The value of the portfolio when Mr Simons dies 10 years later is £247,131 and there is zero inheritance tax to pay. This compares with a more traditional investment, which would only have grown to £166,019 and would have incurred an IHT bill of £66,408. Mr Simons can therefore pass on £247,131 to his heirs, compared with £99,611 if he had used a traditional investment. Growth Mrs James wants to invest some of her money in growth companies. She invests £50,000 for five years. Of this, £10,000 are previous gains that she can shelter from CGT in the EIS. Income and capital gains tax reliefs make her starting portfolio £75,429. The investments do well and Mrs James’ portfolio grows at 6.5 per cent a year. After five years, the EIS leaves her with a total of £103,344 compared with £68,504 if she had used a traditional investment. Exit focus Mr Olazabal wants an investment with a predictable exit as soon as possible after the minimum holding period of three years, to minimise risk. He invests £20,000 with no capital gains to protect and 30 per cent tax relief increases his initial investment to £28,571. The investments grow at 6 per cent a year and he exits after four years. At that time, Mr Olazabal’s investment has grown to £36,071 compared with a traditional investment, which would have grown to £25,250. • To find out more about private investment opportunities, visit Rockpool.uk.com Please note: your capital is at risk and there is no guarantee of return. Tax benefits depend on your personal circumstances and compliance with relevant rules. You may not be able to sell your investment when you want .
